contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases refer to the same people and are used to emphasize that business will be destroyed. Alternate translation: "for those who buy and sell goods will be killed" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: for all the merchants will be ruined; all those who weigh out silver will be cut off

contextId.occurrenceNote: The prophet repeats the same phrase almost exactly in order to emphasize how terrible Yahweh's judgment will be and the urgency with which the people must repent. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: before the fierce anger of Yahweh's wrath comes upon you, before the day of the wrath of Yahweh comes upon you

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize the complete destruction of these cities. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: will be abandoned ... will turn into a devastation

contextId.occurrenceNote: "the taunts ... the insults." These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize that both Moab and Ammon have insulted Yahweh. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
These two phrases mean the same thing and refer to the Israelites that survived Yahweh's punishment. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: the remnant of my people ... the remainder of my nation

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing, and emphasize Yahweh's righteousness even among the wicked people in Jerusalem. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh is righteous ... He can do no wrong

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two sentences express the same idea in two different ways in order to emphasize the complete destruction of the cities. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: I have made their streets ruins, so that no one passes over them. Their cities are destroyed so that there is no man inhabiting them

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing and are repeated to emphasize Yahweh's joy that the remnant is restored to him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: He will celebrate over you with joy ... he will be glad over you with a shout for joy

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two lines mean basically the same thing and imply that Yahweh will bring the exiled people back to their homeland. Alternate translation: "At that time I will gather you together and lead you home" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: At that time I will lead you; at that time I will gather you together
